[doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/Swift/true] if the number object’s value and `number` are equal, otherwise [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/Swift/false].

Two `NSNumber` objects are considered equal if they have the same id values or if they have equivalent values (as determined by the [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSNumber/compare(_:)] method).

# isEqual(to:)

**Instance Method**

Returns a Boolean value that indicates whether the number object’s value and a given number are equal.

## Declaration

```swift
func isEqual(to number: NSNumber) -> Bool
```

## Parameters

- **number**: The number to compare to the number object’s value.

## Return Value

[doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/Swift/true] if the number object’s value and `number` are equal, otherwise [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/Swift/false].

## Discussion

Two `NSNumber` objects are considered equal if they have the same id values or if they have equivalent values (as determined by the [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSNumber/compare(_:)] method).

This method is more efficient than [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSNumber/compare(_:)] if you know the two objects are numbers.

## Comparing NSNumber Objects

- **compare(_:)**: Returns an `NSComparisonResult` value that indicates whether the number object’s value is greater than, equal to, or less than a given number.
